results.title: Festliches Nuernberg = Nuremberg rally
results.brief_description: Coverage of the 1937 Nuremberg Rally. The film opens with views of Nuremberg immediately prior to the rally. Hitler is seen arriving in Nuremberg by aeroplane and driving through crowd lined streets to a rousing reception. Propaganda shots of factory production, farming activities etc., precede coverage of the rally itself. Shots of massed troops parading before Hitler are followed by a display of military weapons etc. The film closes with night scenes of the rally and a fireworks display. There is no commentary.

results.title: 1893-1901: early Edison films
results.creator_credit: Thomas A. Edison and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: A compilation of 19 Thomas Edison films, some made for use in kinetoscopes others for public projection, averaging less than one minute each. Most are single shot films except ‘McKinley’s Inauguration’ and ‘Admiral Dewey at Manila Bay’ which are made up of several shots. Includes “Washing the Baby” (1893) and “Inauguration of President McKinley” (1896) and what is regarded as the first advertising film.

results.title: 250 million years ago: permian life in Australia
results.creator_credit: Harold Fletcher, Lex Halliday and Australian Museum
results.brief_description: The permian deposits found most notably in the Kimberley’s, North-West Basin and the Hunter Valley are some of the world’s richest fossil deposits. Mostly marine, but some fresh-water and land strata fossils are included. Typical fossils such as butterfly shells, starfish, lace coral, as well as plants and coal seams are highlighted.

results.title: 240 Volts
results.creator_credit: British Petroleum and St John Ambulance Australia
results.brief_description: How to deal with accidents caused by electrical appliances. Firstly turn the power off at the switch. Electrical shocks often cause the heart to stop and is therefore the need for immediate cardiac compression and resuscitation. Shows how to apply exterior ‘heart massage’ and mouth to mouth resuscitation which can save lives.

results.title: 146,000 could live
results.brief_description: Dramatically presents each of the seven danger signals for cancer. Five are represented by people cured of cancer, one by a woman who lost her son to cancer and one by a man who notices a danger signal but found, when he went to a doctor, that he did not have cancer. Originally presented on television. Narrated by Charles S. Cameron.

results.title: A Hundred years underground
results.creator_credit: Jon Rowdon, Edgar H. Anstey, John Shearman, BBC-TV and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: The story of London’s underground railway, from the building of the original Metropolitan line with its steam drawn trains, to its latest addition, the ultra modern Victorian line. Lord Morrison tells how London Transport became the model for similar undertakings throughout the world; artist Henry Moore shows how the tube became a wartime refuge, and tunnel engineers explain the problems, past, present and future, of building and operating this vast system.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jon Rowdon, Edgar H. Anstey, John Shearman, BBC-TV and British Transport Films

results.title: 100 watts 120 volts
results.brief_description: Accompanied by the Bach “Brandonburg Concerto” played by the Munich Bach Orchestra, and two very short segments of musique concrete, this film in great detail shows the fully automated manufacture of light bulbs. Produced for Fred A. Niles Communications.

results.title: Fifty miles from Poona
results.creator_credit: Fali Bilimoria, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film from the heart of India is a story of a rural Hindu family. The film evokes sympathy and understanding for things people everywhere have in common: the love of a farmer for his land, the devotion of a mother to her children. This is the day-to-day life of Vishnu Shevale and his family in the village of Phursangi, fifty miles from Poona.
